body.p: My dear friend

I believe I have not as yet
acknowledged yours of Feby 19. and
in good earth even more I have nothing
worthy of time to write to you.

I send you by mail to day the
Picayune of last Saturday 3d. Inst
in which you will find the paragraph
which I enclose for fear that the
newspaper may not reach you.

Our mutual friend Gutheim asked
me to write a few lines about
you and have it inserted in the
Picayune which I did with pleasure,
and the thought just came to me
that he asked me to send you a copy
of the paper. Perhaps he may have
also sent the paper.

As to your late congregation,
or a majority of them, I hold them
in too little esteem even to say
a few words about them. Let
them alone and their insignificance
will be the sooner discoverd.

We are getting along shortly
here, the people are lukewarm
and pernicious, and a few have
to stand the lament of expense,
in our congregation.

Things did look very squally
at the date of Mr. Touro's last
letter to you, but I am happy
to say that things look a
good deal better now.

As the revd. Nathan has just
this moment come in my office
I shall make him fill the
rest of this sheet
I am my dear friend
yours ever faithfully

TOKEN OF RESPECT.—We see the Hebrew
congregation in Philadelphia have presented the
Rev. Isaac Leeser, who has been their pastor for
twenty-one years, with an elegant service of plate,
consisting of a pair of pitchers, a pair of salvers,
and half a dozen goblets, all of the most splendid
workmanship. Suitable inscriptions express the
high appreciation which the donors have of the
abilities and labors of their minister. The Rev.
Mr. Leeser is the editor of the “Occident,” and
the important services which he has rendered to
his brethren in this country are, we believe, uni-
versally admitted.

I owe you a letter a long time, but
really had so little to communicate of a pleasant nature, and felt
so undesirous of making any comments on the proceedings of the
cabal formed against you, or the lukewarmness shown by such as
profess themselves your friends, in not breaking it up, that I had no
heart for doing what at another time would have been a pleasure.

I have seven subscribers on my list, whose names I will
send you in a few days. The most of them are for the Bible and
the advocate both. There is little spirit in my congregation; but
when the Bible is completed, I have little doubt of being able to
dispose of many copies; its price $6 deters many from subscribing.

It is useless expatiating on my troubles; I have
become callous to them, and am determined not to worry myself
to neutralize the malicious efforts of discontented demagogues against
me. As long as I can ? this place, I continue in my office,
when no longer practicable—away with bib and gown—and
hurra for something more congenial and less annoying.

I will most certainly write you again shortly.
I congratulate you on the handsome testimonial of respect you
have recd. and the address which must be still more satisfactory.
Desiring you to be well and happy which Mrs. N wish her love, also
does I am
Your's Truly
